justification: “The intertemporal choice task has long occupied a central place in the self-control research program … This task … is widely used … [and] successful self-control is defined as selection of a larger option with a greater delay.”
“One of the more successful laboratory paradigms in humans has been the diet choice task, in which poor self-control is defined as choosing the tastier but less healthy item.”
“In reverse contingency tasks, animals must point to one of two rewards in order to get the other … These tasks are often used in animal studies of self-control.”
“In accumulation tasks a reward is available at any time but builds up the longer the animal waits. Gaining a larger reward involves inhibiting the taking of the reward….”
“Exchange tasks require an animal to keep a small reward in their possession for a period of time before trading it back to the experimenter for a bigger reward.”
“The external validity of the [intertemporal choice] task is quite low, compared to other self-control tasks such as the BART task (Lejuez et al., 2002).”

The author notes that after reading becomes automated, “that child is tested on the Stroop task and has difficulty performing accurately in the high conflict condition,” illustrating use of the Stroop as a test of controlled versus automatic processing.
